title: Pep’s wild mistake creates unwanted history
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS FOR the first time, a side has scored six goals in a UEFA Champions League knockout tie and been eliminated. 
For the first time, Pep Guardiola has failed to qualify for the tournament’s semi-finals in his time with Barcelona, Bayern Munich and now City. 
One has a lot to do with the other. 
Had Manuel Pellegrini rocked up to Monaco and picked such a cavalier first XI holding a two goal advantage he would have been criticised heavily afterwards. 
Guardiola will get another off-season to spend, and mould his outfit, but whether you’re a fan of the Spaniard or not, he cannot escape scrutiny for this European exit on away goals after a 6-6 draw on aggregate . Throwing caution to the wind was a reckless tactic, an approach formulated because of a clear lack of trust of the players he has in this squad. True, he inherited plenty of them. But he also spent money before the season and yet was left with two fullbacks who were deemed surplus to requirements by Arsene Wenger years ago, while the club’s best goalkeeper is in Turin. 
His side have fallen well short of the final four that Pellegrini reached last term. 
“All managers make mistakes but I don’t think it was down to a tactical mistake,” Guardiola said. 
“It’s simple. The difference was between the first and the second half. In the second half we tried to win the game, we tried to play. 
“I did it all my career in that way. 
“We wanted to show personality, not to let them think, but they could pass and pass the ball. We forgot to do that in the first half. 
“My mistake was being not able to convince them to do that. I did in the second half but it was too late.” Monaco's first-half blitz 1:26 
ALL OUT ATTACK … 45 MINUTES TOO LATE 
Guardiola made no secret that he was going to send his side out to attack despite holding a two goal advantage from Etihad Stadium. 
The problem with that tactic was City were so incoherent, insipid, disorganised and rattled by Monaco’s pressing and energy that they didn’t even get close to launching a single shot until near the hour mark. It is the first time in seven years they have gone a whole half without a shot. 
Playing Sergio Aguero, Leroy Sane, Raheem Sterling, David Silva and Kevin De Bruyne all in the XI horribly exposed Fernandinho, and City were simply a passenger as they watched their lead dissipate. The goal that kicked City out 0:56 
Belgian De Bruyne was especially disappointing; flat, sloppy and not influential enough given his stature and the game’s magnitude. 
They might have leaked twice, but Guardiola pointed the finger of blame further up the field. 
“No, it’s not about the defence. Today was not about that,” the Spaniard said. “Why was the second half a problem with the defence? The problem was the first half when we were not there.” Tonight's piece probably works best with Pep Guardiola's reaction to the third goal. https://t.co/4zYa8GLIee pic.twitter.com/ogqP24T2QK — Daniel Storey (@danielstorey85) March 15, 2017 
Speaking on The BBC , former Premier League midfielder Trevor Sinclair said: “I thought De Bruyne, Silva, Fernandinho didn’t take responsibility on the ball. 
“They looked shell-shocked at the start by Monaco. From the first kick of the second half they went long and the gaps appeared. They needed to realise that sooner. In the first leg, Yaya Toure did that. It happened too late here.” Manchester City's Kelechi Iheanacho leaves. Source: AP 
Execution on the field let Guardiola down and so his blueprint backfired painfully. 
They arrested the momentum in the second-half when Monaco opted for a more conservative approach; although there were key involvements from all five of those attacking threats they were not decisive enough – especially Sterling with his decision making, while Aguero spurned a hat-trick of chances. 
It was to no avail thanks to Monaco’s late set piece. Manchester City's Kevin De Bruyne, left. Source: AP 
Phil Neville added: “I am not so sure the signings over the last five years have been that good. But when Sane scores I think Pep is thinking ‘this is perfect, we can control the game from here’. Then they concede. 
“Pep Guardiola doesn’t go out there and spend the bulk of his money on defenders. He will be thinking if they had put one of those chances away they would be in the next round.” Pep can have no complaints if heavily criticised. If Pellegrini had blown 2 goal adv to go out,he'd have been panned. He'll be chuckling now — James Ducker (@TelegraphDucker) March 15, 2017 Manchester City with only one midfielder with any defensive nous whatsoever are getting torn to shreds. — Gary Lineker (@GaryLineker) March 15, 2017 Monaco so, so good. #MCFC look terrified. All very well trying to play on front foot, but they've been poor with the ball & terrible without — Oliver Kay (@OliverKayTimes) March 15, 2017 City defending poor + runners not picked up. Monaco quicker, more potent. Mendy (sort of shadowed by Stones) drives ball across, Fabinho 2-0 — Henry Winter (@henrywinter) March 15, 2017 Manchester City's Spanish manager Pep Guardiola. Source: AFP 
DEFENCE AT SEA 
Arsenal copped 10 in two games amongst 16 goals leaked in eight UCL games. 
Manchester City conceded the same amount as their hapless English counterparts. 
One first-half moment, when Willy Caballero threw Bacary Sagna a hospital pass as City tried fruitlessly to play the ball out from the back, summed up the poor decision making Guardiola’s side were making. 
Stones recovered after a shaky start, and found an ally in Rio Ferdinand, who felt he was also exposed by his teammates, particularly with Aleksandar Kolarov chosen at centre-back alongside him. 
“I felt sorry for Stones, he was isolated,” he told BT Sport. Manchester City's Fernandinho reacts at the end of a Champions League. Source: AP 
“The players behind him showed no communication. Stones can do nothing about this [Fabinho goal]. I’d have been fuming.” Pep has picked the wrong team here. Not enough defensive mindset in midfield. Fernandinho getting overrun. — Mark Ogden (@MarkOgden_) March 15, 2017 Can't begin to imagine how frustrating it must be to watch this Man City side defend as a supporter. Horrendous even as a near neutral. — Daniel Storey (@danielstorey85) March 15, 2017 Terrible start. Defence all over the shop. — Mike Keegan (@MikeKeegan_DM) March 15, 2017 
Stones assessed: “Very sloppy. Not up to our standard in the first half. We wanted to correct that but we weren’t clinical enough in both boxes. 
“We didn’t score enough and weren’t defensively solid enough. 
“The second half didn’t reflect the whole scoreline. We were the City people know from this season. We should have scored more. It is a difficult one for us to take. We should have done better and deserve to be in the next round. 
“The gaffer was saying before that the more and more he plays the Champions League it is about the set-pieces. Real Madrid scored from two last week and went through. We weren’t solid enough.” Manchester City's Fernandinho reacts while Monaco's Bernardo Silva jumps. Source: AP 
BREATHLESS MONACO 
Guardiola’s tactic looks even more reckless when you consider that the French outfit’s winner was their 126th goal of the season – already! 
Even without Radamel Falcao, they were a threat, headlined by 18-year-old Kylian Mbappe, already touted as The Next Henry – and delivering on that moniker with each outing. 
Leonardo Jardim has attacking riches all over his field; Bernardo Silva was electric, Thomas Lemar dangerous while fullback Benjamin Mendy and utility Fabinho will be hot property this off-season.
